sp.l: May you receive this bounty from above, Exit Alonzo.
In ten thouſand Curſes; and when Heavens ſtore
Exauſted is, I'll coyn as many more.
This was a happy diſguiſe —
I've gain'd ſo much upon Don Manuel's wife,
She has diſcover'd to me all his life.
He's mine, to gain Alcinda by my Ayd;
And my pretended Love has gain'd the maid.
From her I'll lrarn what brought Alonzo on,
And then I'll do your work, my angry Don!
Here ſhe comes —
O my dear Rogue! what dangers have I trod?
How many weary ſteps? how often rode
Ore hill and dale? through fire and froſt.
Through frights and foes? what Wives? what fortunes loſt?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Time has not chang'd thee, thou art Mingo ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mingo.
sp.l: Thy ſlave my Sultaneſs! both heart and will:
O let me ever hold thee thus —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Here's ſport! —
An Eunuch? a Stalion! I'll ſpoyl your Court.
D'ee hear Sirrah! Villain! Rogue! what are you?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Thy evil Angel, Gorzell! nay tis true:
Gorzell I ſay! haſt thou forgot thy name?
Thy Cheats, thy Murthers too, I can proclame,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Mercy, ſweet Devil mercy! pity me!

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Riſe mortal, and give ear to my decree;
One beauty ſhall be mine, the other thine,
And equally we'll ſhare the pilfer'd coyn;
Diſpatch thy anſwer quick; conſent, and live —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Y'are merciful, take all that I can give.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Then I'm thy friend, and Mingo. Diſcovers himſelf.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Catch'd agen?
'Sdeath how didſt thou diſcover, me or when?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: O never queſtion that, let it ſuffice,
I know you now, and all your Subtleties.
Hold to your bargain, we'll go hand in hand,
And raiſe ſuch plots Fate ſhall not countermand.
That wench will tell me news if you retire —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Th'art my good Angel, take thy own deſire.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: You muſt not ſee it, though I ſeem too kind
To your Tereſa —

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No! no! uſe thy mind — Exit Manuel.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Yes, and thy ſoft pate, long proſperity
Has lull'd the raſcal in ſecurity.
Here comes his fellow trader —

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Dear Eunuch! this has been a tedious day.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: How eagerly this Creature longs for prey?
Time's lazy grown, 'tis yet an hour to night.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: That hour's eternity — let's loſe our ſight,
And make it ever night —

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: O hold! you propheſie your death I fear.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Death! prythee let's go in — and meet it there.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Know then in ſhort,
I'm hir'd to murther you; here's earneſt for't:
sp.stage: Shews the money Alonzo gave him.
sp.l: Your husband loves Alcinda —

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: O baſe ſlave!
Villain! I'll to him ſtrait; I'll tear the knave —

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Stay! you'l undo us both; but if you will,
You may preſerve us both, and Manuel kill.
Diſpatch him roundly, if you love me then
I'll marry you —

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: I'll doe't! thou beſt of men! Exit Tereſa.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Nay ſhe's gone;
My beſt ſaint! my wiſe Medea! what ſpell
Wilt thou invent, old Manuel's rage to quell?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: A powerful charm which he can ne'r withſtand.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Tereſa doats, doats on me, by this hand!
She's ſo jealous of thee too, we ſhall ne'r
Enjoy in quiet while we tarry here.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come, come, there's Villany on foot; my ear
Gave me intellgence, though none appear.
They look like ſaints; for all their pious ſhow,
There may be Murthers, Whores, and Rogues, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I underſtand, therefore 'tis our beſt way,
To make a handſome pack, and march away.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Our Ladies do prepare to meet their Loves,
I muſt along too —

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Mark well how it proves;
And let me know, it may produce a light,
To guide us on in our intended flight.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I'll obſerve, adieu! —

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Ioy of my life, farewell! thus far I thrive;
I muſt be ſuddain, leſt ſo many Eyes
As I imploy, may find my Subtilties.
I'm ſtor'd with Wives, and with a helping friend,
I'll make true uſe o'm; to my propper end.
On fair Roſella lyes my aim, though here
Is my circumference, my centre's there.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Alonzo, with a picture in his hand.

lg.l: The blaſting light'ning darte from the Sky,
Kills not ſo ſure as this tranſpiercing Eye.
Coward Alonzo! ſhall thy Courage ſinck,
At white and red? a Woman make thee ſhrinck.
That thing which I deſpis'd; do I not know,
Beauties like flowr's do fade as faſt as grow?
Why ſhould I love, and think of this? nay more,
That when we have enjoy'd, the paſſions o're,
And w'are aſham'd of that we did adore.
Unruly force of wild deſire! — this frame
Is beautiful as ſhe, this face the ſame,
This I can break, deform it when I pleaſe;
Intruding Age, or any weak diſeaſe,
Will make her pow'rful charms as ſoon decline;
Minds oft' are wicked, though the ſhapes divine.
Folly farewel! this Idle ſenceleſs toy,
And all my paſſion too, thus I deſtroy —

div.stage: Alonzo throwes away the Picture, Feniſe Enters and takes it up. —

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: What ſuddain change is this?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: O happy Feniſe! fair Alcinda's thine,
Fly to the Cypreſs grove, there ſhe'l reſign
Her ſelf into thy armes — be ever bleſt,
I'll ſeek a grave, while thou enjoy'ſt thy reſt.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Hate me for ever—
If I ſeek Joy while you have Diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I love your Miſtriſs Sir! and to prevent
Any unworthy Act, ſo baſe a flame
May tempt me to, I'le fly to hide my ſhame.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: More unto Friendſhip, than to Love I ow,
If you unhappy are, I muſt be ſo.
You made her mine, when all my hope was gone,
'Tis juſt you ſhould enjoy what you have won.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Let it ſuffice in Love I yield to you,
Strive not to conquer me in friendſhip too:
Conceal that tempting Shadow from my ſight;
Thoſe that would cure weak Eyes, ſhould fly the Light.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Is this the Form you love?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: No Painters Art,
Could e'r infuſe more life in ev'ry part.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Fortune is kind, her Bleſſings to divide,
Both may be happy yet, Both ſatisfi'd.
'Tis not Alcinda Sir! but may ſhe be
As kind, as fair Alcinda was to me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Who is it then? There was no other by.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Let's to the place, and there the difference try.
But ſtay they are here —

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Two Suns at once in Beauties glorious Sphere,
Denote ſome change in Loves high State draws near.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Pray Heav'n his Tyranny may now decay.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: In me it ſhall, I'll die or win the day.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Encourag'd by your Goodneſs, I am come
To meet a Bleſſing, or receive my Doom.
More to my Love, then my Offence, is due;
My Change was feigned, but my Love is true.
It is the practice of the Pow'rs above,
To pardon Errors, and accept of Love:
Your Beautie's heav'nly, make your Language ſo:
Will you that pardon which you ask beſtow?
Though you ſo well your eaſie change diſguiſe,
I ſee the marks of Anger in your Eyes.
Remember Feniſe! you did uſe to wooe,
Deſpiſe not Love becauſe 'tis offer'd you.
Will you refuſe me then? Where ſhall I hide?
I bluſh to ask, but dye to be deny'd.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Refuſe you Madam! Will a ſwelling heart
Refuſe a Kingdom? Will a Hermit part
With want, and miſery? by his remove,
To ſhare the bleſſed happineſs above?
My Soul is ſo tranſported with her Bliſs,
I fear, it will believe no Heav'n but this.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: But Fire that's ſlowly rais'd, as late decayes.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Let common Beauties reign by common wayes:
Too much your Beauty, and my Love you wrong,
Light'ning is ſudden, yet no Flame more ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: Powder that ſwiftly fires, as ſoon does waſt.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Yet does the Fire, as long's the Subject laſt.
So ſhall my Love, and never know decay,
But in the Grave, where no Affections ſtay.
That tedious way of Courtſhip you approve,
Shews much of Patience, and but little Love.
Extremes of Paſſion, ſuch as Love inſpires,
As ill are ſuffer'd, as devouring fires:
Mine, grown too pow'rful for my narrow Breaſt,
Preſumes already to diſturb your Reſt.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Madam! one charge from you, would make her yield.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Love has the Day, but Shame would keep the Field.
Your heart is hers, pray truſt me with your hand,
Come Siſter! lend me yours, though Hymen's Band
May be more Ceremonious, may this
Endure as long, and be as firm as his.
Now I pronounce you one—

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: Remember Siſter! you compel my Love.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: The Earth ſhall vaniſh, e're my Faith remove.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.l: With equal joy I meet your noble flame,
I will be ever yours — Pray hide my ſhame.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: That lovely bluſh, looks like the Ev'ning Air,
Whoſe Scarlet-dye proclaims the next day fair:
And ſo may this Prophetickly appear,
For here begins my bliſs, and ends my fear.
With purer Zeal a Heathen never paid
Vows to his Idol, for ſuppoſed Aid,
Then I preſent my Heart, a Gift too low
To ſpeak the Service I will ever owe.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Ladies! Since we are Conquerors thus far,
The great Affairs of Love, as thoſe of War,
Call for Advice to make the Conqueſt good.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: That from our Leaders muſt be underſtood.
Command us Ladies! We will execute.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.p: This place is moſt unfit for ſuch diſpute.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: No Treaty will be heard, to think of that
Will be in vain, the Foe is obſtinate.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Now let us lead you off a glorious Prize,
Why ſhould we truſt our fatal Deſtinies?

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.l: Brave Enemies! you ſhall command our Lives,
But haſty reſolution ſeldom thrives.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: My lovely Miſtriſs! where all Beauties dwell,
True honour of your worthy—Sex, farewel!

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Moſt certain 'tis they are reſolv'd to fly,
And only wait an Opportunity;
Pretend to make a Journey, and take Horſe;
'Tis Policy muſt do't, in vain is Force.
Now Leonella is diſpatch'd with that,
Shall raiſe between their Servants mortal hate.
They both ſhall die before to Morrows Sun;
Nay more, by their own Swords it ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Excellent Mingo! —

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: With Leonella, I'me to meet this night,
I'th' Summer-houſe, for an intended flight.
That muſt be your Retreat, on her lay hold,
For ſhe'll be furniſh'd with a Mine of Gold.
Make haſte away! — be ſure you fail her not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Wit proſper thee, brave Rogue! Exit Manuel.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: O fear it not.
Poor Fool! I'll make thee ſenſible e're long,
That thou haſt ſold thy Welfare for a Song.
An idle ſenſeleſs Tale, can thy dull Brain
Believe, that for thy eaſe I'll take this pain?

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: Here comes my Midnights Ghoſt—

sp.speaker: Tereſ.
sp.l: My beſt delight!
Fate can't deny us happineſs; this night
Old Manuel rides abroad.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: But is it true?

sp.speaker: Tereſ.
sp.p: Juſt now we parted, as I came to you.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: How Goodneſs is abus'd! a meer pretence;
How Rogues may work upon your Innocence?
Alas good Soul! This Night he means to ſpend
I'th' Summer-houſe, there's his long Journeys end:
There he, and modeſt Leonella meet.

sp.speaker: Tereſ.
sp.p: Leonella too, bleſs me!

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Nay, go ſee't;
And if you love me, now you may be mine;
He once remov'd, I will be ever thine:
Here's that will do the work, revenge your wrong:
sp.stage: Gives her a Piſtol and a Dagger.
sp.l: Reſolve it ſuddenly, the time's not long.

sp.speaker: Tereſ.
sp.l: Think not, my little Silence did proceed
From fooliſh pity, no! they both ſhall bleed.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: The Woman you may pardon if you will.

sp.speaker: Tereſ.
sp.p: To rob me of thy love, no! both I'll kill.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: My dear Infanta!

sp.speaker: Tereſ.
sp.p: I'll do't! and meet thee in the Lodge, farewell!

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Curſes purſue thee, how ſhe flyes to Hell?
This one Night paſt, to Morrow all's my own,
And this kind Wretch ſhall die for what I've done:
In Blood I'll wade ere Phebus leave his Bed,
And make my Crimes out-bluſh the Mornings red.
Great Nemeſis! refuſe me not thy Aid
Thy Sacrifice is loſt, if I'm betrai'd. Exit Mingo.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter Don Feniſe alone in his own Houſe.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: How ſweet are all my Sorrows now! how dear
My Suffrings are, now Happineſs draws near!
Though in my Love I met with ſo much trouble,
My Pleaſure will be, as my Care was, double.
Alonzo may have doubts, and jealous fears,
My long experience all ſuſpition clears.
Roſella's Heart, like parched Straw, took fire,
And did as ſwiftly blaze into deſire:
Such flames are ſooneſt quench'd, and have leaſt heat;
My Happineſs as conſtant is as great;
Like noble Metal, which doth long repel
Aſſaulting Flames, that round about it dwell,
But once made hot, does long retain the fire,
So did my dear Alcinda meet deſire;
Her Love came ſlowly, but will ſure remain;
She will be conſtant, though I change again.

Moſt happy Feniſe!
Enter Leonella, and paſſing by him, careleſly drops a Letter.
Ha! ſure it was ſhe;
What makes ſhe here? Why ſhould ſhe fly from me?
This may inform me, ( ••• y hearts delight
The brave Alonzo) pray Heav'n all is right!
Friendſhip allows me liberty to fee.

body.l: Fail not to meet me, as we did agree;
The hour preciſely Twelve, the place you know,
Blind Feniſe ſtill, no ſign of Friendſhip ſhow.
He may obſerve you with a Lovers Eye,
The time ſeems lazy now our joyes are nigh.
My dear Alonzo! haſte, you have my heart;
When once we meet again, we'll never part.

sp.l: It cannot be, ſure my diſtemper'd Joy
Diſtracts my thoughts, and does my ſenſe deſtroy:
Or her fair ſhape which in my fancy lyes,
Sends bright reflections to abuſe my Eyes.
Ha! 'tis, by Heav'n 'tis ſo! And if it be, Leonella peeps into to obſerve him.
O that I wanted Faith, or could not ſee.
Thine-ever-Alcinda! my Tongue ſpeaks this,
To cheat my Heart; or elſe I hear amiſs.
Alcinda falſe! it cannot, ſhall not be;
Yet who can doubt, what they ſo plainly ſee?
O ſhameleſs Woman! to deſtroy ſo ſoon
A happineſs I have ſo hardly won.
The wild Hibernian Waves, and Winter Air,
Are conſtanter than theſe frail Women are:
Like thin Cameleons ſtill they change their hue,
And take freſh flames from ev'ry ſight that's new.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: The Fiſh is caught, I muſt allow him line.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Hell upon Earth! I'll ſpoil their damn'd deſign.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Now I'll upon him while he looks this way—

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: What, can you run ſo well? I'll make you ſtay.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Mercy dear Sir! Oh Heavens! I'm undone;
I ſee my Sentence in your hand,—I'm gone—
Ah noble Sir! you know I muſt obey,
Puniſh not me, if they have gone aſtray.
Gentle Sir pity me! —

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Hear me, thou diſmal Meſſenger of Fate!
Here, take your Charm, giv't to Alonzo ſtrait:
If thou betray'ſt me, with one look, or word,
Thy Sex ſhall not protect thee from my Sword:
Wipe your diſſ • mbling eyes, and get you gone,
Lo • k undiſturb'd as if it were unknown.
Come Fiend! along, ſee here he comes, take heed:
I'll watch you — Alonzo enters.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Fear me not. I'll do the deed.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: This may be yet a damn'd malicious plot,
'Till he confirm it, I believe it not Feniſe hides himſelf.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Ha! welcome Loves pretty Envoy!
Muſt this Night make us happy? Muſt we go?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There's my bus'neſs, if that inform you ſo.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I will not fail, let this engage thee mine.
My Service to my Miſtriſs—

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: So, to thine,
That is, Alcinda; Ah falſe perjur'd Friend!
Thy heart ſhall bleed for this e'r this Night end.
I'll watch thee to thy Saint, before her Eyes,
Thou ſhalt be puniſh'd for thy Perjuries.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Mingo.
sp.l: ABove my higheſt hope! it needs muſt hit,
I love thy Beauty, and adore thy Wit:
But we muſt try to ſend their Men aſide,
They'l ſooner fall, if we their force divide:
Though both are Cowards, yet for thy Loves ſake,
Any ſtrange Project they will undertake.
Can'ſt think of no Deſign? no little Plot?
Hell take 'em Hounds! they are not worth a Thought.
But it muſt be —

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O that's already done.
They are, by this time, in ſo great a fright,
They'l have no ſenſe to trouble us to night.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Thou'ſt Policy enough to rule a State:
Let's to our bus'neſs, for the Night grows late.
Fail not to be i'th' Summer-houſe, adieu!
I muſt not any more be ſeen with you,
For fear of old Tereſa's jealous Head.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: But, when my Ladies ask me how I ſped,
What ſhall I anſwer them? you know they meant
To fly this Night, and therefore was I ſent.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Say they'l attend them, and 'tis ten to one
They'l put up all their Jewels to be gone.
Where to ſecure them, and how, you know.

sp.speaker: Leon,
sp.p: 'Tis done, my Dear! But whither ſhall we go?

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: The time's too ſhort to tell, nor need you ask,
Leave that to me, 't has been my chiefeſt Task
To ſet you on your way; your Paſport's made, Exit Leonella.
Charon ſhall drag you to the Stygian Shade.
Pluto will get a Cooler for your Luſt,
There's roaring Company, and go you muſt.
Ive taken care you ſhall not go alone—
O what a gallant plotting Rogue I'm grown!
I kill but five to night; 'tis true, my hand
Is unconcern'd, I do it by command:
Like ſtately Tyrants, on my pow'rful Breath
Depends the Thred of Life, the Key of Death.
Suppoſe I fall, if Hell payes me a Shame,
Yet ſhall I leave an everlaſting Name.
The hour draws on apace, the Moon ſhines bright,
I'll ſtain her Horns with Blood if all hit right. Exit Mingo.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Laraſco loaden with ridiculous Armour.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: The hour is paſt, and yet ſhe does not come;
My Heart fails me — O that I were at home!
Yes, I do love her, and this Act does ſhow't,
Do I not hazard here my naked Throat?
For ought I know, it may be Planet ſtrook:
Heav'ns! it thunders; no 'twas my Armour ſhook.
I would go home but for the noiſe I make:
What dreadful Acts we Lovers undertake?
Ha! what's that purſues me? a Spright! a Spright!
It follows me, I ſhall be kill'd this Night,
Mercy! ſweet Spright, mercy! It haunts me yet—
Yes 'tis my Shadow: I am blind with Sweat.
O whoreſon Love! what do I undertake
To ſuffer here, for Leonella's ſake!
Din but a wandring Child now ask the way,
Or harmleſs Sheep paſs by that's gone aſtray,
Were this true Cannon proof, down muſt it lye,
My Sword and all, I ſhould the faſter fly.
O Death! a Lyon roars, farewell my Friend!
Ha! 'tis a Beetle; ſurely ſhe intends
To murther me, elſe why ſhould I ſtay here,
Like ſtout Knight-errant, and no Creature near.
Now if I could but pray—
But how can ſuch poor Rogues as I come to't?
When Gentlemen themſelves now cannot do't.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: If ſhe were come, 'twould be a pleaſant Night;
No noiſe ſtirring! I'm in a woful fright!
All in a clammy ſweat; did ſhe not ſwear,
At ten preciſely ſhe would meet me here?
Well Sanchez! if ſome Brother Spright ſhould come
To ſcrape Acquaintance, and conduct thee home;
Some Lovers meagre Ghoſt, ſome crafty Fiend,
Should by thy Garb miſtake thee for a Friend;
Think thee ſome idle Spirit, and command
Thee down to darkneſs, how could'ſt thou withſtand?
Danger from Men, I think I need not fear,
I fright my very ſelf—Ha! who's this here?
In Arms from head to foot! then I'm betrai'd,
Drawn to my Ruine by this wicked Maid.
Falſe deluding Woman! is this thy Love?
Didſt thou not vow to meet me in this Grove?
I may ſteal off, he has not ſeen me yet—

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Fear won't let me pray; Ha! the noiſe of feet!
Oh the Devil! the Devil!

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.p: Where! where! where!

div.stage: Laraſco runs out, and Sanchez after him.

div.head: Scene 3.

sp.speaker: Mingo.
sp.l: 'Tis late, Alonzo does not yet appear;
He promis'd faithfully he would be here.
I hear him coming —
Sir! you are fairly met —
This Credit does increaſe your Servants Debt.
Pardon my boldneſs Sir! before you go,
I will diſcharge part of the Debt I ow.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Honeſt Mingo! although I cannot gueſs
Thy earneſt bus'neſs, I believe no leſs;
I will reward thy care, now ſpeak it out—

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: The Story is ſo ſtrange, that I much doubt
Your want of Faith; and wiſh withall my heart,
That I had better tidings to impart.
Call all that's Man about you, this will make
The ſtrongeſt of your Reſolutions ſhake.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Thy ſtrange beginning makes me fear the end.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Y'are cheated by a Miſtriſs, and a Friend:
They both are falſe—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Malicious Fool beware:
Think not to take me in a jealous Snare.
Thou ly'ſt, nor did a Mortal meet with two
Such bleſſings as they are; ſo kind, ſo true:
Repeat it not again, this I forgive;
After a ſecond blaſphemy thou ſhalt not live.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: So, this is my reward. What will you do?
Pray draw upon your Servant, kill me too.
Yet I'll pronounce it true, and on your Sword,
My loſs of life ſhall juſtifie my word.
This night he takes her with her own conſent,
Yet truſt me not, ſwear they are innocent:
Your Faith's at liberty—Yet go but home,
And kill me there, if Feniſe does not come.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Take heed! I take thy word; but if he do,
I'll kill that faithleſs Friend, and cheriſh you.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: You need not kill him Sir! that's too ſevere,
He may repent it when he meets you there.
Remember Sir! his Faith ne'r knew a Crime,
Nor wandring thought, till this unhappy time.
Will you deſtroy a Friend ſo often prov'd,
Becauſe your Miſtriſs has ſo falſely lov'd?
Perhaps the Lady firſt began to Wooe;
'Tis not ſo ſtrange, to find their Sex untrue.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: No more! th'aſt rais'd an Earthquake in my breaſt,
But through his Blood, I know no way to reſt.
Yet I would ſpare him, but the Crime's too foul,
A ſtrange Convulſion tears my wav'ring Soul:
'Tis but a faithleſs Woman at the moſt,
She ſoon was won, and is as quickly loſt.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: He cools too faſt, I muſt renew his heat;
This brave Reſolve has made you truly great,
Perhaps they'l glory in their baſe ſucceſs,
And call your Mercy ſtupid Eaſineſs—
But let them laugh; your Conſcience ſtill is clear.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Friendſhip be gone! thou haſt no int'reſt here.
Yet, witneſs Heaven! how unwillingly
I take his Life, for He (or I) muſt dye.
'Tis Honour murthers him, that gilded Air,
No other way remains to keep it fair.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Pray think again

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I've thought too much, away!—

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Thou wilt repent thy raſhneſs e'r 'tis day. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: That baſe contriving Eunuch leads him on;
Well Renegado! we ſhall meet anon.
Ye Gods! —
But why ſhould I invoke your partial aid?
By whoſe permiſſion 'tis that I'm betray'd?
Theſe little Crimes of perjur'd Love, you ſlight,
That you may puniſh them—
I know your aim, Revenge is your delight.
But ſince you uſe me thus, I'll ſeize your right,
I will not for your drowzy Juſtice wait,
Ev'n now your Vengeance I'le anticipate.

div.stage: Ezit Feniſe with his Sword drawn.

div.head: Scene 4.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: In this cloſe Summer-houſe, I keep my State,
And like a Prince, diſpoſe of others Fate.
My General ſtout Mingo takes the care
To manage my Affairs of Peace, and War:
If any danger ſprings, from blood that's ſpilt,
I ſhall the profit reap, and he the guilt.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What mutt'ring voice is that which ſtrikes my Ear?
O my unhappy Fate! Don Manuel here!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Is your bus'neſs to me Lady? Let's ſee,
What have you here? pray ſpare your modeſty;
This is too troubleſome for you to bear,
Deliver up your Charge, and walk in here.

div.stage: Enter Tereſa with a Piſtol in one hand, and a Dagger in t'other.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Are you ſo nimble? are your Bloods ſo hot?
Here's Coolers for you—Theſe will marr your Plot.
O my dear Mingo! that thou could'ſt but ſee,
What dangers I deſpiſe to merit thee.

div.stage: Exit Tereſa after Man. and Leon.

div.head: Scene 5.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: This way he'll come —
Pray Sir! think on the ſacred name of Friend,
May this ſad difference have a happy end.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Ha! here he comes! be gone! by Heav'n 'tis he,
My ſeeming Friend: Good Mingo pardon me;
I'll ſtudy how to recompence thy care.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: In your ſucceſs my pains rewarded are.

div.stage: Exit Mingo, but returns again, watching them with his drawn Sword.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: O have I found thee Traytor!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Sir no words —
Our diffrence hears no Umpire but our Swords.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: peeping. Bravely fought Boyes! So, that thruſt was home,
When one is fall'n, then does bold Mingo come.
I'll ſoon diſpatch the other; how, not yet? Alonzo diſarms Feniſe.
Sure they'r immortal, that was kindly met:
Miſchief! what damn'd luck have I? his Sword's loſt.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: O my curſt fortune—Truth is ever croſt.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Now, if th'haſt any thing to ſay make haſt;
But know this very Minute is thy laſt.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Uſe thy advantage, kill me, do baſe man!
I will have Juſtice when we meet again:
There thou ſhalt ſuffer for thy treachery,
And that falſe Woman too for whom I die.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: What means this language Sir? did I not wooe
Thy Miſtriſs for thee, and obtain her too?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Muſt I hear this and live! no way to die!
Do'ſt thou upbraid me with thy Villany?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Thy Crime does in thy ill ſucceſs appear;
Did'ſt thou not come to meet Roſella here?
I knew thy foul intent, I knew it well,
What Charms did'ſt thou imploy? what curſed Spell,
To rob me of her Heart? What canſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Thou kill'ſt me ten times o're in this delay.
Pr'y thee diſpatch, leſt I ſome bluſhes ſhow,
To think thoſe Crimes, thou canſt not bluſh to do.
Let me not ſtand a Witneſs to my ſhame,
Since you, to meet the falſe Alcinda came.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Then we are both abus'd —

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: O helliſh ſpight!
Yet I'll get ſomething, if the reſt hit right. Exit Mingo.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Abus'd! am I awake? did I not ſee,
When Leonella gave a note to thee?
A Letter from Alcinda? and when you
Vow'd not to fail, Ha! is not this true?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: That very Letter you may here peruſe.

div.stage: Feniſe takes the Letter and reads it.

body.head: To Signior Alonzo.
body.l: My breaſt is loaded with unhappy News,
Which onely in your Ears I dare relate;
If y • u vouchſafe your preſence when 'tis late,
Conceal it from your Friend, and come alone;
Elſe you will loſe, and I ſhall be undone.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: O ſubtle Villain! And thou crafty Maid!
What have I done? That I ſhould be betraid?
I fear this is not all,—ſure they intend
Some miſchief to the Ladies e're it end.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Mingo juſt parted hence, we may with ſpeed
Prevent all danger, 'sdeath how faſt you bleed?
Forgive my raſh belief! —

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: I muſt from you
The ſame entreat: But let's the Rogue purſue—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: He ſhall not 'ſcape, I'm ſure he went this way.
My fears grow ſtronger by the leaſt delay. A Piſtol fir'd within.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Ha! a Piſtol! I fear we are too late.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: We will prevent, or we'll revenge their Fate.

div.head: Scene 6.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Oh cruel Witch! inhumane Sorcereſs!
I'm pepper'd now for all my wickedneſs:
Incarnate Devil! for my Ruine ſent!
All Curſes Men and Devils can invent,
And mine beſides, fall on thy bloody Heart—

div.stage: Enter Tereſa with a Dagger in her hand, dragging in Leonella.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Come! come along, I'll teach you a new Art
To couple; do ye roar in conſort now?
Dry'd Dog! I was not good enough for you:
Would ye be yoak'd? I'll ſee ye yoak'd, I will,
You ſhall be joyn'd; what are you roaring ſtill?
Silence! and hear your heavy Doom: Now Dame!
Now bold Huſſey! was there no other Game?
No Pipe but mine to make you dance? I'll try
Who ſhall be Miſtriſs now, of you or I.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Dear Madam! O Heav'ns! hear what I can ſay —

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Noble Signior! pray bow your head this way,
See your Ven'ſon quarter'd, and when that's done,
With you I'll finiſh what I have begun.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: My Royal Donna! dear Tereſa hold!
I'll be thy Slave—

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Poor Fool! thou art too old:
In Prayers ſpend thy time, for 'tis but ſhort,
Or curſe me if thou wilt, I care not for't.
Have at thee—

div.stage: Enter Laraſco running in his Armour, and Perez following him in his Shroud.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.p: Oh a Ghoſt! a Ghoſt away!—

sp.speaker: Perez.
sp.p: No Ghoſt! I am no Ghoſt! good Neighbors ſtay—

div.stage: All run off in a fright, Perez purſuing them.

div.head: Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter Mingo with Bags of Money.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Now Fortune, if thou haſt not ſworn my fall,
Grant me one happy hour, and have at all.
The Houſe is yet my own; and here's my Mint —
If all my Plots ſhould fail; the Devil's in't. Exit Mingo.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Now Madam! does the tedious time draw nigh,
When we ſhall have our long wiſh'd Liberty.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: May this bleſt Night, like ſome auſpicious Star,
Shine bright in Fames Eternal Calendar.
May it produce no ſad unhappy Birth,
But be to all the World a Night of Mirth.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: May after times, when they would ſum their bliſs,
Wiſh happy Dayes, and all their Nights like this.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: This way, your Servants wonder at your ſtay —
The watchful Cock foretells approaching day.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: Good Mingo! lead the way; how my heart beats?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: This little trouble all our joy compleats.
What noiſe is that? A noiſe at the dore.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: Hell! they have forc'd the dore—

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: If Fate frown now, I'll never truſt it more.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: That noiſe has made me fear we are undone.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: Yet, through this other dore we may be gone.

div.stage: Mingo going out, meets Feniſe and Alonzo, with their Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: Then to my laſt ſhift— He draws a pair of Piſtols.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Sir! y' are fairly met —
This favor does encreaſe your Servants debt.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: Not ſo well met as you imagine yet.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Yes Hell-hound! you are;
And ere you part, I will reward your care,
Your care to ruin us — thou canſt not fly.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: If you but ſtir a foot, they both ſhall dye. He preſents the Piſtols.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Inhuman Dog!

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Good words, ſtand further yet—
What I have done, I need not now repeat.
I know you'll kill me, but before I dye,
I'll make you ſharers in my miſery.
Your Miſtriſſes ſhall lead the way: D' ye ſtare!
Their Deſtinies within my power are;
And thus I'll ruine them—

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Hold! good Rogue hold!
We'll be thy Slaves, thou ſhalt have Mines of Gold.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: A Kingdom ſhall not buy one hours delay:
Yet, to torment you more, a while I'll ſtay.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Art thou ſo heartleſs▪ and ſo childiſh grown,
To fight with Women? when this Act is known,
Thou wilt be branded with a Cowards name,
A fearful Rogue, Art thou ſo loſt to ſhame?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: So loſt to policy?
For if to miſchief th'art ſo firmly bent,
By killing us thou may'ſt thy death prevent.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: That's well advis'd —

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.l: I dare thy ſharpeſt ſpight, and will not grieve
To dye, ſo my Alonzo may but live.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: See what thou doeſt, thou bloody Devil! do!

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Seal up your lips, or I'll begin with you.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.l: Brave Villain do! I will requite thy pain,
If ſpight won't make thee ſhoot, yet do't for gain.
Here's Gold and Jewels, if theſe will not do,
I'll call thee Coward; nay I'll curſe thee too.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: No more! I'll quickly end this Generous ſtrife.
Theſe Ladies never injur'd me, 'tis true,
But I'll kill them, to be reveng'd of you.

div.stage: He flaſhes in the pan; and Alonzo and Feniſe diſarm him.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Thou cruel Rogue! now we'll command thy fate.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: I will not beg your love, nor fear your hate.
Had not my fooliſh pity ſtaid my hand,
My Life had never been at your command.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: Ano • her Storm begins, ere this is gone.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: If 'tis your Father, we are yet undone.

sp.speaker: Laraſco within.
sp.p: For pity's ſake let's in, who ere you be.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: That's my Raſcal's voice.

sp.speaker: Lar. within.
sp.p: Ay Sir! 'tis me! 'tis me! Enter Laraſco arm'd.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: What does this folly mean?

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: O Sir! as I to meet my Love did go forth,
The very Devil follow'd me; and ſo forth—

div.stage: Enter Manuel, Leonella, Tereſa, falling over one another for haſte— followed by Sanchez in a Shroud—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: What tricks are theſe?
Speak Devil! or I'll kill thee if I can.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Hold! good Sir hold! I am your very Man. Pulls off his Shroud.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There's the Original of all this Rout.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Were ever things ſo croſly brought about?
Nay Sir 'tis true; and had my Plots hit right,
There had not one of you ſurviv'd this Night.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: O my dear Father! —

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Lady you miſtake, nay I'll make you known:
Since I am loſt, I will not fall alone.
He's not your Father, he's a Rogue, a Cheat,
He is in nothing, but in Miſchief, great.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Malicious Rogue! dear Daughter hear him not:
He's raving mad now he has miſs'd his Plot.
Dear Child lead me to Bed, I'm very ſick —

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: To Bed! to th' Gallows; this is a meer trick,
To get off—

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: Let him not uſe my Father ſo —

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.p: Madam! he's a Villain, and your mortal Foe.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Mingo ſpeak out, what is it thou canſt ſay?

sp.speaker: Tereſ.
sp.p: Damn'd Lyes! miſchievous Lyes! lead him away—

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Woman hear thy Charge—
My Crime's ſo great, and ſo prodigious grown,
Though I beg pardon, I can hope for none.
But when their faults in competition come,
Mine are but Cyphers, theirs a total Sum.
Had you not Siſters once, whom you think loſt?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Nay, more than think, we know that they were drown'd.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Sir? ſpare your Sighs, the Ladies ſoon are found.
When Don Valaſco your brave Father dy'd,
You being too young to be your Siſters Guide,
Were left with her, to noble Pedro's care;
Your honour'd Father Sir— To Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Thou ſeek'ſt delayes in Story fetch'd ſo far.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: All this we know, and how my Father ſtrove,
To joyn our Families with Bonds of Love.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Then how our Siſters with Don Pedro went,
When in Peru he had a Government:
We know the time when they took Ship again,
But never heard when they return'd to Spain.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: The reſt I can relate, and mean to do,
More in Revenge to them, than Love to you.
The Sea mov'd gently, and with flatt'ring Gales,
The am'rous Wind did court the flying Sails.
But Fate, that knows a thouſand paths to Death,
Sent a Diſeaſe to take your Father's Breath.
To Sanchez his old Servant, and a Maid,
He left your Siſters, and the Wealth he had;
With careful duty, to reſtore again
Their Charge to you, when they return'd to Spain.
But in the very Port, they met with one
Gorzell, a cruel tatter'd Pickaroon;
Sanchez they murther'd, made the reſt their prey,
And took your Siſters very names away.
What they did ſince is partly known to you,
None but themſelves know what they meant to do:
This is the Villain, that the curſed Maid,
By whoſe infernal Plots they were betrai'd:
This Womans names Guttarze, that Mans Gorzell,
By whoſe inhuman hands poor Sanchez fell.
And thoſe your Siſters are, thoſe Ladies there!
What Heav'n decrees, cannot be alter'd here.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: O that we could believe thee —

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: What ſay you?

sp.speaker: Man. and Tereſ.
sp.p: Mercy! mercy Gentlemen! 'tis too true.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Which is my Siſter? which muſt be my Bride?

sp.speaker: Tereſ.
sp.l: Y'have fix'd thoſe Knots your Father long ſince ty'd;
Madam Alcinda, Sir, your Siſter is,
And you Roſella are Don Fenis's.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Exceſs of happineſs! thy Life's thy own, To Mingo
Dangers ſo great, ſo ſuddenly o'reblown,
Make all our joyes like pleaſing Dreams appear.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.l: I cannot look this way without a Tear.
Can I ſee him, I once call'd Father, kneel,
And weep to me?—

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p: Methinks I fear him ſtill.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: You ſhall forgive him—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: The greateſt Injuries were yours; if you
Can pardon them, with all my Heart I do.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: But we forget the blackeſt Crime they did,
Although we pardon them, for that they'll bleed.
Poor murther'd Sanchez does for Vengeance cry,
The Law will ſeize them, and for that they'll dye.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Cruel Woman! had not thy reſtleſs Will
Urg'd on his death, he had been living ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thou fooliſh Man! why wouldſt thou hear me then?
Nature allows our Sex leſs Wit than Men,
That you may rule us when we go aſide;
Had I been govern'd, Sanchez had not dy'd.

sp.speaker: Roſel.
sp.p: No other wayes to ſave their lives? pray try.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Madam! there is, this time they ſhall not dye.
Look on me well, have you not known this Face?
Time has not chang'd it much from what it was.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis he! 'tis he! good Sanchez pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: O Sanchez! we confeſs our cruelty:
Pray forgive us—

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: May your forgiveneſs be,
From all the World as hearty as from me.
Since I have ſeen my Miſtriſſes again,
No more remembrance of my Wounds remain.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Then you are free, but ere this Sun goes down,
We charge ye every one to leave the Town.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Where we reſide be never ſeen again,
The Law ſhall ſeize ye if we meet in Spain.

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: Pox o' thy trembling Paw! hadſt thou but dy'd,
Or done thy work, I had been ſatisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Curſe on thy plotting pate, and wheedling tongue,
Hadſt thou been hang'd we yet had flouriſh'd long.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Hard-hearted Mingo! wouldſt thou murther me?

sp.speaker: Ming.
sp.l: No pretty Rogue! I was to marry thee.
Save your Lordſhip mighty Manuel hight!
And eke your fair La-dee Tereſa bright.
Great Don! pray ſhut your Lordly Gate, 'gainſt all
Of your own Sex; hate ev'ry thing that's Male.
Such tempting traſh would make a Saint grow vain:
Take heed no ſmooth face't Eunuch come again —

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: No more!
Sanchez I to his former place reſtore.
Let's to the Sacred Temple haſte, and pay
Glad thanks to Heaven for this happy day.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Let ſmiling Hymen, with his Nuptial bands,
As we have joyn'd our Hearts, unite our Hands.
Now all our Doubts and Fears, with joyes are crown'd,
Our Cares are loſt, and our loſt Siſters found.

lg.l: VVHen Wit, and Native Beauty found Succeſs,
Without a daz'ling Scene, or gaudy Dreſs,
Then Playes were good, and wholeſom your Amour;
But when theſe downright Bleſſings pleas'd no more,
Poets, from France, fetch'd new Intrigue, and Plot,
Kind Women, new French Words, and Faſhions got:
And finding all French Tricks ſo much did pleaſe,
'T oblige ye more, They got — ev'n their Diſeaſe.
That too did take — and as much Honour gets
As breaking Windows, or not paying Debts.
O 'tis ſo gente! So modiſh! and ſo fine!
To ſhrug and cry, Faith Jack! I drink no Wine:
For I've a ſwinging Clap this very time —
Poets ſaw this, and brought their Stages Crimes,
Chang'd Comedy to Farce, and Senſe to Rimes.
That took your very Souls —
But now, you are ſo ſtrangely hum'rous grown,
That even theſe, your dear Regalio's will not down:
The neweſt Miſs, with all her little Arts,
Sometimes can't ſoften your obdurate hearts:
At other times, you are ſo far from Pride,
A ſwarthy Gipſie would be deify'd.
Then, to your Friends, you tell ſuch horrid Lyes,
You had a Pers'n of Honour in diſguiſe!
Dam'ee the pretty'st Creature! O ſuch Eyes —
No Play without a new Machine will do,
Shortly, Your Miſs must act with Engine to:
For brisk, and pretty, you will cry at laſt,
Can ſhe Curvet? and is ſhe Thorough-pac't?
Y'have Fiddle, and Motion now, and all That —
'Zbud! I wonder what a Devil you'd be at.
If you perſiſt in theſe lewd damning wayes,
You'll have no more new Miſſes; nor new Playes.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAge 4. line 23. read Feniſe for Mingo: p. 14. l. 24. r. and for are: p. 16. l. 15. r. Her Sword—p. 24. l. 6. r. liv'd here—p. 29. l. 11. r. or for od: p. 33. l. 11. r. ſo baſely—for ſo bravely —p. 41. l. 3. r. talk for take: l. 33. r. Sot for Scot: p. 43. l. 1. r. a for her: p. 45. l. 24. r. thouſand—Curſes: l. 31. r. learn for lrarn: p. 48. l. 14. r. darted for darte: p. 57. l. 12. r. did for din: p. 59. l. 1. r. ne'r for nor.
